vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/d933e950-1634-494b-8b64-65cdbea493c8">WATER SERVICES (BUILDINGS)</keyword>         <topcClas>Energy and fuel - Environment, conservation and land use</topcClas>         <topcClas>Housing</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Energy Follow Up Survey, 2011</i> (EFUS 2011) aims to provide detailed, up to date information on patterns of household and dwelling energy use. Within this survey, householders are asked questions about the type and usage patterns of the main and secondary heating systems in their homes, the water heating system and usage, dwelling insulation, lighting indoor temperatures and the use of appliances. <br> <br> The EFUS 2011 is a follow up interview survey of a subset of households first visited as part of the <i> English Housing Survey, 2010-2011: Household Data</i> (EHS) (available from the UK Data Archive under SN 7040). It is not possible to link the EFUS 2011 data to the EHS data. The last large-scale national survey to consider the detailed use of heating systems and other sources of energy use in homes was the EFUS 1998 (not available from the UK Data Archive).<br> <br> An additional sub-sample of these households was selected to have temperature loggers and electricity monitors installed. A further stage of the EFUS involved the collection of gas and electricity consumption data from meter readings. For the second edition of the study (November 2014), the raw meter readings data were added to the survey, in the form of 823 separate Excel files. Previously, the study included only the summary data for the meter readings. For details of the metered energy consumption research, see Report 1: Summary of Findings, in the documentation.<br> <br> Further information about EFUS can be found on the government <a class="external" href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/energy-follow-up-survey-efus-2011" title="Energy Follow Up Survey">Energy Follow Up Survey</a> webpage.<br> <br> For the second edition of the study (November 2014), the raw meter readings data were added to the survey, in the form of 823 separate Excel files. Previously, the study included only the summary data for the meter readings. For details of the metered energy consumption research, see Report 1: Summary of Findings, in the documentation.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Data covers patterns of household and dwelling energy use, including detailed information on the use of heating systems, cooking and appliance use in households.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="single" date="2011-01-01T00:00:00Z">2011</timePrd>         <collDate>Interviews: December 2010 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd April 2011;<br>Temperature Loggers: November 2011 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd February 2012</collDate>         <nation>England</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Respondents to the <i> English Housing Survey, 2010-2011: Household Data</i>. An additional sub-sample of these households was selected to have temperature loggers and electricity monitors installed. A further stage of the EFUS involved the collection of gas and electricity consumption data from meter readings.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Cross-sectional (one-time) study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>An EFUS study previously ran in 2008, but the data are not held at the UK Data Archive.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>GfK NOP</dataCollector>         <sampProc>The EHS is a systematic random sample from the Postcode Address File. Respondents from the first two quarters of the EHS (April to November 2010) who had agreed to a further interview were approached. The quarters passed to the EFUS survey team were chosen as they were available in time to conduct the survey, and were as close as possible to the start of the EFUS interview to minimise the chance of changes to the dwelling or household. When this sample was considered to be exhausted, Building Research Establishment (BRE) supplied an additional 400 cases from the third quarter of the EHS in February 2010.</sampProc>         <deviat>2,616 households</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Physical measurements</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Available to all registered users for any use</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required. Available to all registered users. The depositor may be informed about usage.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
